page.title: 15QUARRYING IN GRETTON
page.content: The limestone in and around Gretton contained iron ore, and evidence of quarrying and smelting goes back to Roman times. In 1910, blast furnaces were built in Corby. By 1931, there was severe unemployment in Gretton, but in that year Stuart and LLoyds (later to become British Steel Corporation) opened the iron and steel tubeworks, again in Corby. This, together with the need for houses as a result. wiped out the unemployment in the village. In the early 1980's the quarries closed, once again making many people unemployed. The railway lines which transported the ore to the ironworks were taken up. Most quarries were filled in and handed back to the farmers. Some were planted with trees and relandscaped, others have been left and have water in the bottom.
